coredata.dc:title: The adsorption of oxygen on Ag(110): a new view of structure and bonding
coredata.dc:creator: Bange, K.
Madey, T.E.
Sass, J.K.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
We have used ESDIAD (electron stimulated desorption ion angular distributions) to characterize the structure and bonding of O2 on Ag(110). The data indicate that both atomic oxygen (T ads > 300 K) and molecular oxygen (T ads ⋍ 80 K) are bonded in configurations which cause ion desorption in directions along [001] azimuths. Possible structures are discussed which are at variance with existing models of the oxygen-Ag(110) system.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 113, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 January 1985 THE ADSORPTION OF OXYGEN ON Ag(l 10)- A NEW VIEW OF STRUCTURE AND BONDING K BANGE * -2 , TJE. MADEY and J X. SASS * Surface Science Division, National Bureau of Standards, Gaithersburg. Maryland 20899, USA Received 17 September 1984; in final form 8 October 1984 We have used ESDIAD (electron stimulated desorption ion angular distributions) to characterize the structure and bond- ing of 0; on Ag(l 10). The data indicate that both atomic oxygen (Fads > 300 K) and molecular oxygen (7'ads 3 8 K)are bonded in configurations which cause ion desorption in directions: ulong [001] azimuths- Possible structures are discussed which are at variance with existing models of the oxygen Ag(l 10) system- 1. Introduction There has been a great deal of interest, from both experimental and theoretical points of view, in the ad- sorption of oxygen on Ag(llO) [Ij-Much of the recent work focuses on the structures of both molecular 0^ and atomic 0 on Ag(l 10). The present study indicates that there are serious unresolved problems in determin- ing these structures, and points the directions for future work. Adsorption studies of oxygen onto Ag(l 10) at 80 K provide clear evidence for the presence of molecular 0-y on the surface, this has been verified using EELS (high- resolution electron energy loss spectroscopy) [2,3] , thermal desorption spectroscopy isotope mixing [4] , XPS (X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy) [5], and UPS (ultraviolet photoemission spectroscopy) [6] Backx [3] proposed that the molecular 0^ is adsorbed "lying down" in the Ag(l 10) troughs, with the molecular axis along the [110] azimuth. A similar structural assign- ment has been made based on recent surface EXAFS and NEXAFS (surface extended X-ray absorption fine structure, and near edge XAFS) measurements [7] . Upon heating, the molecular state is seen to dissociate * NBS Visiting Scientists. Permanent address: Fritz-Haber-ln- stitut der Max-Planck-Gesellschaft, Faradayweg 4 6, D-1000 Berlin 33/Dahlem. Federal Republic of Germany. 2 Present address: Siemens AG, WRS ESR B, Postfach 120, D- 1000 Berlin 33, Federal Republic of Germany. above "=150 K, leaving atomic oxygen on the surface [2,3,5]. Adsorption at 300 K results in the direct formation of adsorbed atomic oxygen. Whereas the molecular 0^ at 80 K is characterized by a (1 X 1) LEED (low energy electron diffraction) pattern with increased background intensity, the atomic oxygen exhibits fascinating long- range order. A series of(n X 1) overlayer structures are seen, with n = 7 to n = 2, indicating a coverage range from 0 as 1/7 to 0 "s 1/2 [8]. Ion scattering experiments (ISS) on the (2 X 1) structure indicate that the oxygen atoms are situated in the troughs between rows of first- layer Ag atoms [9] . Quantitative LEED intensity anal- yses of the (2X1) structure have been performed using thirteen different structural models [10] , all of which assume 0 or 0^ adsorbed in high-symmetry sites. The authors conclude that the n, idel of oxygen atoms in the bridge sites -within the troughs of the substrate sur- faces is better than the others in approaching agreement with experiment, but that none of the models tested was satisfactory [10]. The authors suggest that motion of the substrate atoms as a result of adsorption of oxy- gen (i.e., reconstruction) may be responsible for the lack of agreement between theory and experiment. In the present work, we have used a combination of ESDIAD (electron stimulated desorption ion angular distribution) and LEED to study the structures of both molecular and atomic oxygen on Ag(l 10). Because the ion desorption angles in ESDIAD are related to the ini- tial bond angles on the surface [II], direct structural 56 Volume 113, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 January 1985 information is attainable using this method. In con- trast to the previously reported models for 0/Ag(l 10) [1,3,7 10], we find evidence that both molecular and atomic oxygen are not bound in high-symmetry sites within the troughs: The dominant bonding characteris- tic is the fact that the Ag 0 bond has an azimuthal component perpendicular to the rows of atoms, in [001] directions- We are unable to deduce the precise identity of the bonding sites, but we can eliminate an entire class of high-symmetry sites on experimental grounds. The systematics of the data suggest also that there may be reconstruction and/or diffusion of 0 be- neath the substrate as the surface is heated. 2. Experimental procedures The ultrahigh-vacuum apparatus used for these studies has been described in detail previously [11]- The sample was a single-crystal disk whose preparation has been discussed [12]. The crystal could be cooled to 80 K, and heated resistively to T> 800 K. The sample was cleaned by 500 eV aron ion bombardment, followed by brief anneals at 800 K; sample cleanliness was verified by Auger electron spectroscopy (AES). 0^ was dosed onto the sample using a small-bore tube directed at the sample, providing a direct flux roughly 100X the ran- dom background 0-t flux. Oxygen coverages were esti- mated using AES intensities (2 keV, 2 fiA), with cali- bration points provided by the characteristic (n X 1) oxygen-induced LEED patterns. The ESDIAD/LEED detector contained hemispheri- cal grids, a double microchannel plate image intensifier, and a fluorescent screen for viewing the patterns [11]. The ion mass and kinetic energy were measured using a quadrupole mass spectrometer (QMS); typical electron energies were 160 300 eV, at a beam current ^ 5 X 10-8 A. To view and photograph the ESDIAD patterns, a bias voltage of l 60 V was applied to the sample (in order to compress the patterns). Measurements of polar ion desorption angles were made under zero-bias condi- tions, using both the ESDIAD detector and the QMS; the peak in the angular distribution was determined within 2 . 3. Results The LEED data obtained in this work are in good agreement with previous measurements [8,10] For ad- sorption at r^ 250 K, streaks appear in the LEED pat- tern; upon heating to ^ 300 K, a series of(n X 1) pat- terns is seen to develop as coverage increases. Adsorp- tion at 80 K produces a (1 X 1) pattern at all oxygen coverages; the (n X I) patterns develop upon heating to ^ 300 K- The sharpest LEED patterns appear after heating to 450 K [10]. Upon dosing the clean Ag(l 10) surface with oxygen at 80 or 300 K, an O"1' ESD signal is observed using the QMS. Fig. 1 illustrates the dependence of the ESD O'1" signal and of the oxygen (KW) AES signal on the oxygen exposure, at both 300 and 80 K. The shape of the 300 K AES curve agrees well with the work func- tion curve ofEngelhardt and Menzel [8]. Although the exposure is given in arbitrary units, a rough calibration as well as comparison with the data of Engelhardt and Menzel [8] indicate that 1 arbitrary unit =1 langmuir. Also shown in fig-1 are the exposure regimes where (n X 1) LEED patterns are seen at T~^ 300 K- The saturated (2 X 1) layer is assumed to correspond to fig =0-5 monolayers [1,7 9]. Fig. 1. Adsorption of oxygen on Ag(llO): growth of 0(KW) peak-to-peak Auger signal and ESD O* ion yield as a function of exposure to molecular 0;; adsorption temperature of 300 K (top panel) and 80 K (bottom panel). 1 arbitrary exposure unit "1 langmuir (1 X 10~6 Ton s). 57 Volume 113, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 January 1985 Note that the 0+ ion yield rises monotonically with oxygen exposure at low exposures (<500 L, for 'S0.3 ML) at both 80 and 300 K. To within the experimental uncertainty the CY^ yield parallels the AES signal at low exposures at both adsorption temperatures, indicat- ing a proportionality between 0^ and oxygen coverage. Only for coverages 0.3 ML, where both sets of 0^ yield data pass through maxima, is there a significant departure from the proportionality Note that the maxi- mum ion yields are different at 80 and 300 K; also the saturation AES 0(KW) signal is ' ! 0% greater at 80 K than at 300 K. A key problem in ESD measurements concerns the question of "minority" or "'majority" sites- does the ESD signal arise solely from adsorption at steps or de- fects (minority sites) [13,14], or is the signal charac- teristic of a majority of the adsorbed monolayer? The functional forms of both the C^ versus exposure curves of fig. 1 are characteristic of adsorption proces- ses in which ESD is believed to be sampling the majority of surface species- For example, when CO adsorbs on many metals, the results are similar to the data of fig- 1. the 0"*" ESD yield increases in proportion to the CO coverage for low exposures, and passes through a maxi- mum at high coverages due to molecule molecule inter- actions [15] . In contrast, when ESD is believed to in- volve minority states, there is (characteristically) an in- duction period at low coverages, where the ESD ion yield is very small [13,14]. At higher coverages, when steps and defects are populated and surface reaction products (e.g., oxides) are formed, a high ESO ion yield appears: such behavior has been seen for many systems, including oxygen on tungsten surfaces [13, 14] and 0/Ti(0001) [16]. Only in a recent study of oxygen on Pd(l 11) has it been suggested that a high ESD 0''" yield can arise from minority species at low oxygen coverages [17] The adsorption behavior is dif- ferent from the present case, however. CiTo] Fig- 2. LEED and CT (c) O* ESDIAD for all ESDIAD patterns, ESDIAD patterns for oxygen on Afi(llO), Ca) clean LEED pattern, (b) O* ESDIAD for "20 L Oy, at 80 K, 500 L Oa at 80 K, (d)-(f) effect of heating on an <al00 L Oz exposure, (d) 80 K, (c) 160 K, (f) 350 K. For the total electron energy was 300 eV, with a bia5 potential of 160 eV. 58 Volume 113. number CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4 January 1985 Based on the data of fig 1, we suggest that the O"1" ESD signals arising from adsorption of both molecular 0^ (adsorption at 80 K.) [1 5] and atomic oxygen (adsorption at 300 K) [1 3,5] anse from a majority of the adsorbed species at low oxygen doses. This is an important point which bears on the utility ofESDIAD for determining the structures of adsorbed molecular and atomic oxygen on Ag(l 10). Note also that the maximum in the O'1' ESD signal is believed to arise from increased neutralization processes due to ad- sorbate adsorbate interactions [15]. The O* ESDIAD characteristics for oxygen on Ag(l 10) are illustrated in fig. 2. Fig 2a, the clean LEED pattern, is included to provide an orientational reference. As shown in fig. 2b, adsorption of0- at 80 K produces an ESDIAD pattern dominated by two beams symmetric about the surface normal, oriented along [001] azimuths. The beams increase in intensity as the coverage increases, as shown in fig. 2c. At higher coverages at 80 K there is an increase in background intensity, but no new beams are seen. ESDIAD pro- vides a direct view of surface structure in real space [11,12], and it is clear that O4' desorbas along an azi- muth perpendicular to the atom rows. As the surface is heated, there are dramatic changes in the ESDIAD patterns, as illustrated in the sequence of fig. 2d-2f- The two beams at 80 K (fig. 2d) "col- lapse" to a small angular separation at 155 K (fig. 2e); further heating causes two smaller beams to diverge and become clearly resolved (fig. 2f). In all cases, the only ion detected is O^ and the beams are directed along equivalent [001] azimuths. Fig 3 is a plot of the polar desorption angle 0 of the O'1" beam center, measured with respect to the sur- face normal along the [001] azimuth. In each case, the surface was heated to the indicated T for 1 s and cooled to 80 K for the angle measurements, which were made under field-free conditions. The value ofOp is constant at 20 2 up to 150 K, at which temperature 0p drops precipitously to 6 2 . Upon further heating, 0p increases and reaches a constant value of 12 2 for r> 250 K, until the 0^ signal disappears following oxygen desorption at T> 700 K. The functional form of the O4" desorption angle 0- versus temperature curve is essentially independent of the initial oxygen coverage. The only significant difference is that the temperature at which 0p decreases from 20 increases with increas- ing oxygen coverage, from 125 to 175 K. 100 200 300 i-OO 500 Tempeiolure T (K) Fig-3. Polar angle of 0"''desorption along [001] azimuth as a function of temperature to which crystal was heated for 1 s following adsorption of' 0.33 monolaycrs of O-i on Ag(llO). Angular measurements made under tie'd-frce conditions (bias potential = 0 V). We caii correlate the data of figs- 2 and 3 with t-.e wealth of previous measurements of oxygen on Ag(llO) [1-10] - The 0^ state which forms ai 80 K and which produces the two-beam ESDIAD patterns stable to r=s 150 K (figs. 2b-2d) is clearly molecular. Part of the molecular 0^ layer desorbs without isotopic mixing at *$ 175 K [4], and the remainder dissociates to form an atomic layer [2,3,5]. The layer apparently becomes mobile above as250 K, when ordered LEED patterns are first observed- Thus, we suggest tliat the 0+ beam at 9 = 20 arises from molecular 0^ stable over the range 80 to ^150 K, the 0"*" beam at 0-12 is due to atomic 0 which is ordered into long-range arrays for T> 250 K, and the "collapsed" O'1" beams in the range 150 250 K are characteristic of the transition region from dis- ordered atomic and molecular oxygen to ordered atom- ic oxygen. 4. Discussion In order to formulate models for the bonding of molecular 0^ to metal surfaces, it is instructive to ex- amine the coordination chemistry ofdioxygen-metal complexes. Vaska [18] has indicated th^i nearly all currently known O^ metal compounds can convenient- ly be divided into two types according to the charac- 59 Volume 113, number 1 CHEMICAL FHYSIC5 LETTLR5 4 January 1985 teristics of the dioxygen ligand Superoxo (I) complexes are those containg covalently bonded dioxygen re- sembling O^; they have structures of the type M 0^ or M O-^O""^, and are characterized by dioxygen vibrational frequencies in the range 1075 1195 cm~1. Peroxo (II) complexes contain covalently bonded oxygen resembling-M^- and M'O-Q-M^ with dioxygen vibrational frequencies in the range 740 932 cm"1 [19,20] The low frequency of the dioxygen stretch (640 cm-1) on Ag(l 10) [3,4] has led to the suggestion of a peroxo (II) structure with an electron transfer from Ag to 0^ of 1.7 e~; the 0^ species was presumed to lie in and parallel to the Ag(l 10) troughs, with the 0 0 bond along the [110] azimuths. This model is hard to reconcile with the ESDIAD results (fig. 3) in which 0+ is seen to desorb along [001] azimuths. The ESDIAD data could be consistent with either a peroxo or super- oxo model ofO^ adsorption, but it appears to be es- sential that the 0 0 bond have a component along the [001] azimuths. The simplest bonding picture would involve On bonded end-on to single Ag atoms, slightly inclined away from the surface normal along the [001] azimuths: 0- Ag Ag Ag Evidence for adsorption of molecular oxygen with the 0 0 axis nearly perpendicular to the surface of Cu(l 10) has been found in the angle resolved UPS mea- surements ofDiDio et al. [21] ,so this structure is not unprecedented. Other simple pictures of molecular 0^ adsorbing in atop or bridging positions across the trough of the un- reconstructed surface also can be envisioned: in fact, slightly distorted versions of some of the molecular 0^ models proposed by Zanazzi et al. (figs. 3h and 3i of ref. [10]) are possible candidates. They clearly did not Fit the LEED (2 X 1) structural data because the LEED experiments were made on what we now know to be an atomic 0 layer produced by heating to 450 K. We turn now to the structure of atomic oxygen on Ag(110) and begin with a discussion of the ESD data and their implications. At first it appears unusual that a significant ESD 0'1" signal is obtained from oxygen on silver, since intense 0'1' signals are associated most often with oxygen on metals known to form maximal valency oxides (e g., W03, Mo03, TiO^) [13,14,16]: in these cases, desorption of0"'' can be initiated by an interatomic Auger decay process [22]. However, 0'1" ESD is seen also from metals (Ni [23,24], Fe [23], Ag, present work) which do not form maximal valency oxides. A necessary condition for desorption of0'*' is simply that the electronic excitation in the repulsive Ag 0"1" state must have a long enough lifetime (10~14 10~15 s) so that ionic desorption will occur. A detailed discussion of ESD mechanisms is beyond the scope of this paper, and the interested reader is referred to refs [25,26]. It is sufficient to observe here that an ESD 0+ signal from Ag(l 10) is not surprising. Now, we consider the bonding information attain- able from ESD and ESDIAD measurements. In a study of the adsorption of atomic oxygen on planar and stepped tungsten surfaces [13], it became cleat that oxygen adsorbed in high-symmetry, high-coordination sites (i.e. bonded to ==3 substrate atoms) did not pro- duce a measureable O4" ESD signal. However, oxygen atoms adsorbed at step edges in sites of reduced coor- dination (bonded to one or perhaps two substrate atoms) were responsible for a high ESD O'1' yield. It now appears on both experimental and theoretical grounds that the ion neutralization rate due to electron transfer from substrate to the electronically-excited ad- sorbate is related to the adsorbate substrate coordina- tion, and that the desorption of singly-coordinated (i.e. singly-bonded) species generally is favored over multi- ply-bonded ones. Feibelman [25] has discussed the reasons for this, which are related to the timescales for localization of the excitation. For the present case, we suggest that the desorption of 0'1' from atomic oxygen on Ag(l 10) is most likely to occur from a aite of re- duced coordination in which an 0 atom is bonded to a single surface Ag atom, or at most, to two Ag atoms. For agreement with the ESDIAD results, it is necessary that the Ag 0 bond have an azinnuthal component along the [001] azimuth. This also means that the 0 cannot be in a high-symmetry site such as directly atop a substrate atom, or in a two-fold bridge, Rather, the 0 atom is in a non-high-symmetry position off to the sied of the atom rows, e.g., displaced from the high- symmetry "long bridge" configuration in the [001] direction. A site like the asymmetric pseudo bridge bonding site for 0/Ni(001) proposed by Demuth et al. [27] is another possible example. The recent angle resolved UPS measurements ofPnnce et al. [28] using 60 Volume 113, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 4JanuaJy 1985 polarized light further indicates that the 0 atoms a7e located in mirror planes oriented along the [001] direc- tion. In the above discussion, a tacit assumption has been that the Ag(l 10) surface is not reconstructed dunng oxygen adsorption In fact, the binding energy of atom- ic oxygen is 3.3 eV/atom [1] and the heat of sublima- tion ofAg is 3.4 eV/atom; because these energies are comparable, it is likely that the surface Ag atoms can be displaced from their "bulk" positions during oxygen adsorption. Zanazzi et al [10] have also suggested that the poor fit of LEED theory to their structural models was probably due to motion of substrate atoms as a consequence of the adsorption of oxygen. If such re- construction does occur, the ESDIAD data impose the previously stated condition on possible models- the Ag 0 bond must have an azimuthal component along the [001] direction. Evidence that reconstruction may occur dunng 0 atom adsorption is given in figs. 2 and 3, where motion of the 0^ beams occurs as a function of temperature during dissociation of molecular 0^- The "collapse" and subsequent separation of the two beams is consistent with substrate and/or adsorbate motion At high temperatures (S 600 K) there may be dif- fusion ofO into the bulk, as suggested also in ref. [10]. At these temperatures, there may also be a minority state contribution to the O"1' ESD signal: there is a measureable O* yield even when AES indicates little 0 remaining on the surface [17] . Finally, we address the relation between the mea- sured ESDIAD polar angle 6 and the angle between the adsorbed 0 atom and the Ag substrate. It is known that ion trajectories can be distorted strongly by the interaction between ion and surface image force, so that the measured polar angle is usually different from the initial polar angle [11,29,30]; the azimuthal angles are expected to suffer little or no distortion- Miskovic et al. [30] have derived analytical expressions for the trajectories of ESD ions desorbing from a perfectly smooth conducting surface. It is somewhat difficult to apply these expressions in the case of oxygen on Ag(l 10) because of the uncertainty in locating the image plane on this atomically rough surface, and the uncertainty in locating the 0 atom with respect to the image plane. In general, however, the calculations dem- onstrate that perturbations of the ion trajectories are minimal for polar angles close to the surface normal, so that the measured (Y^ angles (12 , 20 ) are probably not significantly different from the Ag 0 surface an- gles. Under the influence of the image force alone, the ion trajectories are bent away from the normal, to larger polar angles; the final measurement will be in- fluenced by ion neutralization effects also. In summary, we have found that the structures of both molecular and atomic oxygen on Ag(l 10), as de- tected using ESDIAD, are characterized by adsorption in non-high-symmetry sites with Ag 0 bond compo- nents along [001] azimuths. To help determine wheth- er or not the ESDIAD, L ED, EXAFS and NEXAFS methods are all measuring the same species, i e. to see if there are different states of oxygen to which each is sensitive, we suggest that the LEED [10] and SEXAFS [7] data be tested with new structural models ofoxy- gen/Ag(l 10) bonding consistent with the present mea- surements. To help determine wheth- er or not the ESDIAD, L ED, EXAFS and NEXAFS methods are all measuring the same species, i e. to see if there are different states of oxygen to which each is sensitive, we suggest that the LEED [10] and SEXAFS [7] data be tested with new structural models ofoxy- gen/Ag(l 10) bonding consistent with the present mea- surements. head.ce:title: The adsorption of oxygen on Ag(110): a new view of structure and bonding

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Surface Science Division, National Bureau of Standards, Goithersburg, Maryland 20899, USA

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: Present address: Siemens AG, WRS ESR B, Postfach 120, D-1000 Berlin 33, Federal Republic of Germany.
NBS Visiting Scientists. Permanent address: Fritz-Haber-Institut der Max-Planck-Gesellschaft, Faradayweg 4–6, D-1000 Berlin 33/Dahlem, Federal Republic of Germany.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: We have used ESDIAD (electron stimulated desorption ion angular distributions) to characterize the structure and bonding of O2 on Ag(110). The data indicate that both atomic oxygen (T ads > 300 K) and molecular oxygen (T ads ⋍ 80 K) are bonded in configurations which cause ion desorption in directions along [001] azimuths. Possible structures are discussed which are at variance with existing models of the oxygen-Ag(110) system.

ce:other-ref.ce:textref: A. Puschmann, I. Haase and A. Bradshaw, Surface Sci., to be published; in preparation

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Proceedings of the 7th International Vacuum Congress and 3rd International Conference on Solid Surfaces

ce:other-ref.ce:textref: K. Bange, T.E. Madey and J.K. Sass, Surface Sci., to be published
R.A. DiDio, D. Zehner and E.W. Plummer, to be published
K.C. Prince, G. Paolucci and A.M. Bradshaw, Surface Sci., to be published
